instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2179: What is A2179? A2179 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2020 with EMC 3302, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01958..
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.820-1958: What is 820-1958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.P5VG3S_EN: What is P5VG3S_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_G3S power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with burned out <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>, no visible liquid damage
threads.message:
Ive replaced one visibly blown <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> and reloaded the TBT rom and have both USB C ports now achieving 20volts but thats it - still no boot.

20volts 90mA with battery disconnected.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3v
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P5VG3S</SIGNAL> 12.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>P5VG3S_EN_DLY</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>P5VG3S_EN</SIGNAL> 0v (no enable issued by PMU to produce 5v)


PMIC LDOs are present
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1.1v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1.8v

<SIGNAL>PMU_PVDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL> 0v

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with burned out <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>, no visible liquid damage
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with burned out <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>, no visible liquid damage
threads.message:
Ive tried for hours to get it into DFU mode with keyboard commands both inside case and with external keyboards and with battery connected with no luck.

Ive tried jumping <SIGNAL>SOC_FORCE_DFU</SIGNAL> (pin 1 <RESISTOR>R8010</RESISTOR>) line to <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> (pin 1 <CAPACITOR>C7840</CAPACITOR>) with no luck

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with burned out <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>, no visible liquid damage
threads.message:
You should try soldering a switch between <SIGNAL>SOC_FORCE_DFU</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>; use 5-10cm cables.
This will help you to force it.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with burned out <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>, no visible liquid damage
threads.message:
Just tried a switch with leads - still no luck getting into DFU mode. Verified <SIGNAL>SOC_FORCE_DFU</SIGNAL> goes from low to high.
Tried with battery and trackpad connected too.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with burned out <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>, no visible liquid damage
threads.message: is there anything else I can try to get it to respond?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with burned out <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP>, no visible liquid damage
threads.message:
Many people have problems to get their macs into DFU.
You may need to test several times.
Also be sure to follow all the steps.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://logi.wiki/index.php/DFU_Mode_Restore_(Macs)[/URL]
